title: Partial-differential-algebraic equations of nonlinear dynamics by Physics-Informed Neural-Network: (I) Operator splitting and framework assessment
abstract:
Several forms for constructing novel physics-informed neural-networks (PINNs) for the solution of partial-differential-algebraic equations (PDAEs) based on derivative operator splitting are proposed, using the nonlinear Kirchhoff rod as a prototype for demonstration.

The present work is a natural extension of our review paper in [1] aiming at both experts and first-time learners of both deep learning and PINN frameworks, among which the open-source DeepXDE (DDE) [2] is likely the most well documented framework with many examples. Yet, we encountered some pathological problems (time shift, amplification, static solutions) and proposed novel methods to resolve them.

Among these novel methods are the PDE forms, which evolve from the lower-level form with fewer unknown dependent variables (e.g., displacements, slope, finite extension) to higher-level form with more dependent variables (e.g., forces, moments, momenta, etc.), in addition to those from lower-level forms. Traditionally, the highest-level form, the balance-of-momenta form, is the starting point for (hand) deriving the lowest-level form through a tedious (and error prone) process of successive substitutions. The next step in a finite element method is to discretize the lowest-level form upon forming a weak form and linearization with appropriate interpolation functions, followed by their implementation in a code and testing. The time-consuming tedium in all of these steps could be bypassed by applying the proposed novel PINN directly to the highest-level form.

We also developed a script based on JAX, the High Performance Array Computing. For the axial motion of elastic bar, while our JAX script did not show the pathological problems of DDE-T (DDE with TensorFlow backend), it is slower than DDE-T. Moreover, that DDE-T itself being more efficient in higher-level form than in lower-level form makes working directly with higher-level form even more attractive in addition to the advantages mentioned further above.

Since coming up with an appropriate learning-rate schedule for a good solution is more art than science, we systematically codified in detail our experience running optimization through a normalization/standardization of the network-training process so readers can reproduce our results. As the training speed is most likely related to the gradient computation, we provide snippets of our DDE-T script and our JAX script with detailed annotation.

sections.title: 1 Introduction
sections.content:
As a prototype of partial-differential-algebraic equations (PDAEs) for novel physics-informed neural network (PINN) formulations, the geometrically-exact rod with no shear is considered here, starting with the assumption often attributed to Kirchhoff (or Kirchhoff-Clebsch, or Kirchhoff-Love, or Kirchhoff-Clebsch-Love; see the review in [3] [4] and the references therein): Plane cross section initially perpendicular to the undeformed centroidal line remains perpendicular to the deformed centroidal line.

Our formulation's starting point is similar to that in [4], then takes on a different direction as we are aiming at developing a finite deformable rod, without introducing approximations, culminating in a system of nonlinear partial differential equations, complemented by algebraic expressions with derivatives (AEDs), i.e., a PDAE system of the form

$D^{(k)}({∂xuj,∂x−1uj,…,∂Dxuj},{∂tuj,∂t−1uj,…,∂tQuj},uj,t)=0,u(x,t):={∂xuj,∂−1uj,…,∂Dxuj},{∂tuj,∂t−1uj,…,∂tQuj},Uj$(82)

where $D^{(k)}$ is a nonlinear differential operator, operating on $u(x, t)$, which collects the unknown dependent variables $\{u_j\}$ and their partial derivatives, with $\{k, i, j, p, q\}$ being indices to be defined later in the paper.

An example of a PDAE system is the motion of the Kirchhoff-rod Form-1 (Section 3.2) Eq. (41), Eq. (42), Eq. (36), Eq. (43); these equations form an implicit system of nonlinear PDEs in terms of the four dependent variables $\{\bar{u}, \bar{v}, \bar{\alpha}\}, \bar{k}$. While it is possible to eliminate two dependent variables $\{\bar{\alpha}, \bar{k}\}$ by

sections.title: 2 PDEAS: Beam formulations with no shear
sections.content: As a particular case of the general partial-differential-algebraic equations (PDEAs) represented by Eq. (82), consider the geometrically-exact beam with no shear, i.e., the Kirchhoff rod, a derivation for which is first provided followed by pointing out the inconsistency of such formulation based on geometrically-exact beam with shear. Then approximations are introduced to recover the classical linear Euler-Bernoulli beam with axial deformation in preparation for an implementation in a PINN framework, beginning with DDE-T, then with JAX.

sections.title: 2.1 Geometrically-exact beam with no shear, Kirchhoff rod
sections.content: All equations are first derived in dimensional form, then subsequently converted to non-dimensional form.

sections.title: 2.1.1 Kinematics, finite extension, constitutive relations
sections.content:
Figure 1 provides a pictorial definition of the finite extension $e$ expressed as

$e = \frac{dl}{dL}-1 = \frac{dl}{dX}-1$, with $dL = dX$, and $dl = (1 + e)dX$, (2)

with the following kinematics of deformation $(x, y) = \Phi_0(X, t)$ such that

$x = X + u(x,t) \Rightarrow dx = dX + du = dl \cos{\alpha}$, $y = v(X, t) \Rightarrow dy = dv = dl \sin{\alpha}$, (3)

where $\{u(X,t), v(X,t)\}$ are the axial and transversal displacements, respectively. The gradients of the spatial coordinates $(x, y)$ with respect to the material coordinate $X$ are then:

$\frac{dx}{dX} = \frac{du}{dL} + u^{(1)} \frac{dl \cos{\alpha}}{dL} = (1 + e) \cos{\alpha}$, $\frac{dy}{dX} = v^{(1)} = v^{(1)} \frac{dl \cos{\alpha}}{dL} = (1 + e) \sin{\alpha}$, (4)

which give rise to the expression for the slope $\alpha$ of the centroidal line, together with the relations involving finite extension $e$ and the displacements $(u, v)$:

$\tan{\alpha} = \frac{v^{(1)}}{1 + u^{(1)}}$, $e \cos{\alpha} = 1 + u^{(1)} - \cos{\alpha}$, $e \sin{\alpha} = v^{(1)} - \sin{\alpha}$. (5)

The last two expressions in Eq. (5)2,3 provide then the extension for $e$ in terms of the displacements $(u, v)$ and the slope $\alpha$:

$e = [(1 + u^{(1)} - \cos{\alpha})^2 + (v^{(1)} - \sin{\alpha})^2]^{1/2}$ (6)

Using Eq. (4), some convenient variables involving the extension $e$ and the displacement derivatives $(u^{(1)}, v^{(1)})$ are introduced:

$c^2 := (1 + e)^2 = [1 + u^{(1)}]^2 + [v^{(1)}]^2 \Rightarrow e = {([1 + u^{(1)}]^2 + [v^{(1)}]^2)}^{1/2} - 1 =: k-1$ (7)

The traditional elastic axial and bending constitutive relations are:

$N = EAe$, $M = EI\alpha^{(1)}$ (8)

sections.title: 2.1.2 Balance of momenta, non-dimensional form
sections.content:
Referring to Figure 1, the equilibrium of forces and moment of the depicted infinitesimal segment leads to the following expressions.

Balance of linear momentum along X axis:

$\sum F_x = 0 = [(N \cos{\alpha})|_{x+dx} - (N \cos{\alpha})|_{x}] - [(S \sin{\alpha})|_{x+dx} - (S \sin{\alpha})|_{x}] + f_{appl} dx - f_{inert} dx = d(N \cos{\alpha}) - d(S \sin{\alpha}) + f_x dx - (\rho A dx) \ddot{u}$. (9)

Balance of linear momentum along Y axis:

$\sum F_y = 0 = [(N \sin{\alpha})|_{x+dx} - (N \sin{\alpha})|_{x}] - [(S \cos{\alpha})|_{x+dx} - (S \cos{\alpha})|_{x}] + f_{appl} dx - f_{inert} dx = d(N \sin{\alpha}) - d(S \cos{\alpha}) + f_y dx - (\rho A dx) \ddot{v}$. (10)

Balance of angular momentum:

$\sum M|_a = 0 = -M(X) + M(X + dX) + S(X + dX) dl + M_{appl} - M_{inert}$, (11)

with $M_{appl} = O(dl^2)$, $M_{inert} = \rho I_A dl \ddot{\alpha}$ (12)

sections.title: Non-dimensionalization
sections.content:
Coordinates and displacements, using Eq. (3):

$\frac{X}{L} = \bar{X}$, $\frac{x}{L} = \bar{x} = \bar{X} + \bar{u}$, $\bar{u} = \frac{u}{L}$, $\frac{y}{L} = \frac{v}{L} = \bar{v}$, $\bar{v} = \frac{v}{L}$ (14)

$[X] = [x] = [\bar{X}] = [\bar{y}] = [\bar{u}] = 1$ (15)

Normal force and shear force:

$\bar{N} = \frac{L^2}{EI}N$, with $[\frac{L^2}{EI}] = \frac{L^2}{\frac{FL^2}{L^2}} = \frac{L^2}{F}$, and $[ ar{N}] = \frac{F}{F}= 1$, so $[ ar{N}]=1$, (16)

$\bar{S} = \frac{L^2}{EI}S$, and $[ ar{S}]=1$ (17)

In Eq. (16), $[ ar{N}]=F$ means the axial force $N$ has the dimension of force, denoted by $F$, and similarly for length $L$, mass $M$, and time $T$ as used in Eq. (20) below.

Distributed force using Eq. (16):

$\bar{f} = \frac{L^3}{EI}f$, with $[ ar{f}] = \frac{L^3}{\frac{FL^2}{L^2}} = \frac{LF}{FL} = 1$. (18)

Moment:

$\bar{M} = \frac{L}{EI}M$, since $[ ar{M}] = \frac{L}{\frac{FL^2}{L^2}} [ ar{M}] = \frac{L}{\frac{FL}{L}} = 1$ (19)

Time:

$\tau := L^2 \sqrt{\frac{(\rho A)}{(EI)}}$; since $[\frac{\rho A}{EI}] = \frac{M/L}{F L^2/ L^4} = \frac{ML/T^2}{FL^2} = \frac{ML/(MT^{-2}L)}{FL^2} = \frac{M/L}{F L^2/(M/L)} = \frac{M/(T^2 L^{-3})}{F}= \frac{T^2}{L^4}$, thus $[	au] = T$ (20)

$\bar{t} = \frac{t}{T}$ and $[t] = 1$ (21)

Balance of momenta

Space derivative of a generic force $F(X)$:

$\bar{F}^{(1)} = \frac{d}{dX} \bar{F}(X) = \frac{dX}{dX} \frac{d}{dX} (\frac{L}{EI}F(X)) = \frac{L}{L} \frac{L^3}{EI} \frac{d}{dX} \bar{F}(X) = \frac{L EI}{EI} \bar{F}^{(1)}$ (22)

sections.title: Time derivatives of a generic displacement function x(t) with length dimension L:
sections.content:
$\ddot{x} = \frac{d}{d\bar{t}} \frac{d}{d\bar{t}} \frac{[Lx(t)]}{T^2} = \frac{L}{T^2} \frac{dx(t)}{d\bar{t}} = \frac{L}{T^2} \bar{x}$, (23)

$\dddot{x} = \frac{L}{T^2} \frac{d}{d\bar{t}} \frac{d^2x(t)}{(d\bar{t})^2} = \frac{L}{T^2} \frac{\frac{EI}{\rho AL^3}}{(\frac{EI}{\rho AL^4})^2} \bar{x} = \frac{L \frac{EI}{EA L^3}}{T^2} \frac{\bar{x}}{PA L^2} = \frac{L \frac{EI}{EI L^3}}{T^2} \bar{x} = \frac{EI}{PAL^2} \bar{x}$ (24)

Generic balance of linear momentum in non-dimensional form using Eq. (21), Eq. (22) and Eq. (24):

$\bar{F}^{(1)} + \bar{f} = \frac{\rho A}{\frac{EI}{L^3}} \ddot{X} \Rightarrow \bar{F}^{(1)} + \bar{f} = \ddot{\bar{X}}$ (25)

Space derivative of displacements and extension using Eq. (14):

$\frac{du(X, t)}{dX} = \frac{d}{d\bar{X}} \frac{[Lu(\bar{x}, t)]}{dX} = \frac{d\bar{u}(\bar{x}, t)}{d\bar{x}} \frac{dX}{dX} =: u^{(1)} \Rightarrow \frac{d\bar{u}(\bar{x}, t)}{d\bar{x}} =: \bar{u}^{(1)}$, and $v^{(1)} = \bar{v}^{(1)}$ (26)

Similarly, using Eq. (26) in Eqs. (5)-(6) and Eq. (7), we have:

$\alpha = \bar{\alpha}$, $e = \bar{e}$, $e \cos{\alpha} = \bar{e} \cos{\bar{\alpha}}$, $e \sin{\alpha} = \bar{e} \sin{\bar{\alpha}}$, $c = \bar{c}$, $\bar{k} = \bar{k}$ (27)

Using Eq. (25) in Eq. (9) and Eq. (10), together with Eq. (27)1, we have the balance of linear momenta along X and Y as:

$(\bar{N} \cos{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} - (\bar{S} \sin{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} + f_x = \ddot{\bar{u}}$, $(\bar{N} \sin{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} + (\bar{S} \cos{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} + f_y = \ddot{\bar{v}}$ (28)

Space derivative of moment from Eq. (19) and similar to Eq. (22), we have:

$\bar{M}^{(1)} = \frac{EI}{L^2} \bar{M}^{(1)}$ (29)

Balance of angular momentum. Eq. (13) in non-dimensional form based on Eq. (29), Eq. (17), and Eq. (27)5:

$\bar{M}^{(1)} + \bar{c} \bar{S} = 0 \Rightarrow \bar{M}^{(1)} + \tau \bar{S} = 0$, (30)

which can be expressed in terms of the space derivative of the displacement components $(u, v)$ as defined in Eq. (7), using Eq. (26).

sections.title: 2.1.3 Constitutive relations, non-dimensional form
sections.content:
Non-dimensional constitutive relation for axial deformation:

$\bar{N} = \frac{F}{FL} = E Ae \Rightarrow \bar{N} = \frac{EA\bar{e}}{\frac{EI}{AL^2}} = \frac{A L^2}{I} \bar{e} = s\bar{e}$, (31)

with non-dimensional slenderness parameter $s$ and its inverse being the rotundness $r$

$s := \frac{AL^2}{I} \Leftrightarrow r := s^{-1} = \frac{I}{AL^2}$ (32)

The space derivative of the slope $\alpha$ of the centroidal line is:

$\bar{\alpha}^{(1)} = \frac{\partial \alpha}{\partial \bar{X}} = \frac{\partial \alpha}{\partial \bar{X}} \frac{dX}{dX} = \frac{L}{\frac{1}{L}} \bar{\alpha}^{(1)}$ (33)

Non-dimensional constitutive relations for bending deformation using Eq. (8), Eq. (19), and Eq. (33):

$\bar{M} = EI \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \Rightarrow \bar{M} = \bar{\alpha}^{(1)}$. (34)

sections.title: 2.1.4 Equations of motion, non-dimensional form
sections.content: The first two terms in each of the non-dimensional balance of linear momentum in X and in Y direction, respectively, as expressed in Eq. (28) can be written in terms of displacements as follows. Using the axial constitutive relation Eq. (31) and the definition of $\alpha$ in Eq. (5) together with the expressions related to the

sections.title: finite extension e defined in Eqs. (5)-(6), and again using Eq. (27), we have:
sections.content:
$\bar{N} \cos{\bar{\alpha}} = s \bar{e} \cos{\bar{\alpha}} = s \frac{I}{A L^2} [1 + \bar{u}^{(1)} - \cos{\bar{\alpha}}]$, $\bar{N} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} = s \bar{e} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} = s \frac{I}{A L^2} [v^{(1)} - \sin{\bar{\alpha}}]$, (35)

$\tan{\bar{\alpha}} = \frac{\bar{v}^{(1)}}{1 + \bar{u}^{(1)}}$, (36)

from which the first term as a function of $(\bar{N}, \bar{\alpha})$ with a space derivative, in each equation in Eq. (28) is, respectively:

$(\bar{N} \cos{\alpha})^{(1)} = \frac{I}{A L^2} [\bar{u}^{(2)} + \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}}]$, $(\bar{N} \sin{\alpha})^{(1)} = \frac{I}{A L^2} [\bar{v}^{(2)} - \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}}]$ (37)

Next, using the balance of angular momentum, yielding the moment-shear relation with finite-extension effect, in Eq. (30), the bending constitutive relation in Eq. (34), and the definition of $\alpha$ in Eq. (5), and making use of Eq. (27)1, we obtain:

$\bar{S} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} = -k \bar{M}^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} = -k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}}$, $\bar{S} \cos{\bar{\alpha}} = -k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}}$ (38)

$- (\bar{S} \sin{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} = - (k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} = - [k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)}]^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} + k [\bar{\alpha}^{(2)}] \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}}$ (39)

$+ (\bar{S} \cos{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} = (-k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}})^{(1)} = - [k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)}]^{(1)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}} + k [\bar{\alpha}^{(2)}] \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}}^{(1)}$ (40)

Using Eq. (37) for the derivative of the terms with $(\bar{N}, \bar{\alpha})$, and Eqs. (39)-(40) for the derivative of the terms with $(\bar{S}, \bar{\alpha})$ in Eq. (28), the non-dimensionalized balance of linear momenta, we obtain the equations of motion in terms of the displacements $(u, v)$.

Axial equation of motion:

$s [\bar{u}^{(2)} + \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}}] + [k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)}]^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} + [k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)}] \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}} + f_x = \ddot{\bar{u}}$, (41)

Transversal equation of motion:

$s [\bar{v}^{(2)} - \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}}] - [k \bar{\alpha}^{(2)}]^{(1)} \cos{\bar{\alpha}} + k [\bar{\alpha}^{(2)}] \bar{\alpha}^{(1)} \sin{\bar{\alpha}} + F_y = \ddot{\bar{v}}$, (42)

where the slenderness $s$ was defined in Eq. (32)1, and $k$ in Eq. (27), Eq. (26), and Eq. (7), reproduced here so all relevant terms in the above equations of motion are grouped together for convenience:

$s := \frac{A L^2}{I}$,

$k = {\{ [1 + \bar{u}^{(1)}]^2 + [\bar{v}^{(1)}]^2 \}}^{-1/2}$ (43)

sections.title: 2.1.5 Input parameters: Boundary and initial conditions, distributed load
sections.content:
In addition to the slenderness $s$ defined in Eq. (32) and the input distributed load functions $f_x(\bar{x},t)$ and $f_y(\bar{X}, t)$ for Eqs. (41)-(42), respectively, i.e.,

$\bar{F_x}(\bar{x},t) = f_x(\bar{x},t)$, $\bar{F_y}(\bar{x},t) = f_y(\bar{x},t)$, (44)

there are six input parameters in each of the two sets of boundary conditions considered here: One set for cantilever beam, and another for simply-supported beam.

Cantilever beam

sections.title: Clamped end: Three input parameters are the prescribed displacements and rotation {$û, \u0177, \u0102$}, such that
sections.content:
At $X = 0$, $u(X = 0, t) = \hat{u}$, $v(0,t) = \hat{v}$, $\alpha(0, t) = \hat{\alpha}$ (45)

Free end: Three input parameters, two algebraic expressions with derivatives (AEDs).

At $X = 1$, $s \bar{e}(1,t) = \bar{N}$, $-k(1,t)M^{(1)}(1,t) = -k(1,t)\alpha^{(2)}(1,t) = \bar{S}$, $\alpha^{(1)} (1,t) = \bar{M}$. (46)

The three input parameters in Eq. (46) are the prescribed concentrated forces and moment $\{\bar{N}, \bar{S}, \bar{M}\}$, and the two AEDs are Eqs. (46)1,2 due to the expression of $\bar{e}$ as a result of Eqs. {(5), (6), (26), (27)2}, and the expression of $k$ in Eq. (43), with both $\bar{e}$ and $k$ involving the first-order derivatives $\bar{u}^{(1)}$ and $\bar{v}^{(1)}$. These AEDs together with the differential equations from the balance of momenta form a system of differential-algebraic equations (DAEs).

Simply-supported beam

At $X = 0$, $u(0, t) = \hat{u}_0$, $v(0,t) = \hat{v}_0$, $\alpha^{(1)} (0,t) = \bar{M}_0$ (47)

At $X = 1$, $s \bar{e}(1,t) = \bar{N}_1$, $\bar{v}(1,t) = \bar{v}_1$, $\alpha^{(1)} (0,t) = \bar{M}_1$ (48)

Because of the expression for $\bar{e}$ in Eq. (48)1, the equations of motion of the simply-supported beam also form a system of DAEs.

Remark 2.1. AEDs cannot be imposed exactly. Because "complex" boundary conditions are AEDs, such as Eq. (48)1, which involve derivatives of the dependent variables, they cannot be imposed exactly by hard constraints. Only "simple" boundary conditions not involving derivatives of dependent variables, such as Eqs.(48)2,3, can be imposed exactly.

There are four prescribed functions for the four initial conditions:

$\alpha(X, 0) = \alpha_0(X)$, $\dot{\alpha}(X, 0) = \dot{\alpha}_0(X)$ (49)

$\bar{u}(X, 0) = \bar{u}_0(X)$, $\dot{\bar{v}}(X, 0) = \dot{\bar{v}}_0(X)$, (50)

sections.title: 2.2 Inconsistency, reduction from geometrically-exact beam with shear
sections.content:
Deformation map of centroidal line [19], which is valid for both geometrically-exact beam without shear (Figure 1) and with shear (Figure 2, is written as:

$\Phi_0(X, t) = [X + u(X,t)] e_1 + v(X, t)e_2$, (51)

where $\{e_1, e_2\}$ are the spatial basis vectors. The material basis vectors $\{t_1, t_2\}$ attached to the cross section are then in terms of the rotation $\theta$ of the cross section

$t_1(X, t) = \cos{\theta}(X, t) \cdot e_1 + \sin{\theta}(X,t)\cdot e_2$, $t_2(X, t) = - \sin{\theta}(X, t) \cdot e_1 + \cos{\theta}(X, t) \cdot e_2$ . (52)

$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} t_1 \\ t_2 \end{array} \right\} := \begin{pmatrix} \cos{\theta} & \sin{\theta} \\ -\sin{\theta} & \cos{\theta} \end{pmatrix} \left\{ \begin{array}{l} e_1 \\ e_2 \end{array} \right\} =: A^T \left\{ \begin{array}{l} e_1 \\ e_2 \end{array} \right\}$ (53)

Spatial strains $\{\gamma_1, \gamma_2\}$ and material strain $\{\Gamma_1, \Gamma_2\}$; see Figure 2:

$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \gamma_1 \\ \gamma_2 \end{array} \right\} = \left\{ \begin{array}{l} [1 + u^{(1)} - \cos{\theta}] \\ [v^{(1)} - \sin{\theta}] \end{array} \right\} = \begin{pmatrix} (1 + e) \cos{\alpha} - \cos{\theta} \\ (1+e) \sin{\alpha} - \sin{\theta} \end{pmatrix} = A^T \left\{ \begin{array}{l} \Gamma_1 \\ \Gamma_2 \end{array} \right\}$ (54)

sections.title: Next, using Eq. (4) in Eq. (54), we obtain
sections.content:
$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \gamma_1 \\ \gamma_2 \end{array} \right\} = \left\{ \begin{array}{l} (1 + e) \cos{\alpha} - \cos{\theta} \\ (1+e) \sin{\alpha} - \sin{\theta} \end{array} \right\}$ (55)

and in the case where $\theta = \alpha$, we have

$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \gamma_1 \\ \gamma_2 \end{array} \right\} = \left\{ \begin{array}{l} e \cos{\alpha} \\ e \sin{\alpha} \end{array} \right\} = A^T \left\{ \begin{array}{l} \Gamma_1 \\ \Gamma_2 \end{array} \right\} = \left\{ \begin{array}{l} N \\ 0 \end{array} \right\}$, (56)

which indicates that there is zero shear deformation, and thus zero shear force S, since the material (axial and shear) forces $\{N_1, N_2\} = \{N, S\}$ are computed from the linear constitutive relation [19] as follows:

$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} N_1 \\ N_2 \end{array} \right\} = \begin{pmatrix} EA & 0 \\ 0 & G_s A_s \end{pmatrix} \left\{ \begin{array}{l} \Gamma_1 \\ \Gamma_2 \end{array} \right\} = \begin{pmatrix} EA & 0 \\ 0 & \text{GAS} \end{pmatrix} \left\{ \begin{array}{l} e \\ 0 \end{array} \right\} = \left\{ \begin{array}{l} N \\ S \end{array} \right\}$ (57)

But a non-zero shear force S was introduced in Figure 1 and in the balance of linear momenta to derive the equations of motion as done above.

sections.title: Remark 2.2. The authors of [19] cited (among other references) [20], where neither the dynamic problem,
sections.content: nor the computational formulation, was considered. It is also noted that the static “Form 4" in [20] was the result of a projection onto the cross-section basis vectors $\{t_1, t_2\}$, whereas the dynamic Form 4 (Section 3.6) considered here remains in the inertial frame.
